Objectives

The aim of this module is to provide the theoretical and practical scientific,
methodological and technology basis involved in building ontology, which will be
used in building applications that integrate, combine and deduce distributed and
heterogeneous information. In particular, we will present:
the concepts of ontology and annotation in the context of Semantic Web and corporate semantics,
the fundamental theory and best-known ontologies;
languages RDF(S) and OWL,
the methodologies, methods and techniques used in its building that include guidelines for identifying the life-cycle, specification, planning, conceptualisation, correspondences, reuse, reengineering, etc.;
methods and techniques for the annotation of resources and significant applications.
Throughout the entire module open research problems will be set that allow students to provide innovative solutions.
Lectures structure

All lectures, except for the introductory one, will follow this structure:
Presentation (90 minutes)
Discussion about work done during the week (e.g., papers that have been read, assignment that has been carried out) (25 minutes)
Description of work to be done for the following week (5 minutes)
Evaluation

Evaluation will be done on the basis of: weekly work and participation in discussion (10%), ontology building assignment (30%), Linked Data assignment (30%) and research work (30%)
Partial assignments that will be done throughout the academic year, and which are specified in the schedule section, will allow creating the aforementioned ontology building and Linked Data assignments, which will be presented orally on 16/12/2010. The optional research work will have to be submitted in January 2011 (31/01/2011).
The evaluation on July will be on
July 7th
, 15:00, in room 6206. Students must present the ontololgy building and Linked Data assignment, and optionally a research work.

Hands on activities

All hands-on activities must be submitted by e-mail to masterr10@delicias.dia.fi.upm.es.
Design and implement an ontology to be used for linked data generation taking into account open and public data in Spanish. As an example of the type of data you should use, go to the Web page of Ministerio de Medio Ambiente [2] . You will see there that data are available in different formats (Microsoft Excel, PDF,  ASCII files, etc. Taking into account the particular data you have selected, you should:
Build an ontology following the NeOn methodology.
Transform the data sources into RDF
Link the data with existing data in the Web of Data. Examples of potential resources are: DBPedia [4], GeoLinkedData [5] or GeoNames [6]. You can also use for searching resources sig.ma [7]. If you plan to represent stastistical information, you should use SCOVO [8].
Implement the ontology you can use any of the following tools: RDF Gravity [9], Jena [10], NOR2O [11] and the  NeOn Toolkit [12].
